Definition of π, and the derivation of C=2πR :
Given a circle of radius R>0 and center o. Put n isosceles triangles inside it with their equal sides (S with S=R) along the radii of the circle and apices at o. The circumference C of the circle subtends an angle ϑ. The base of each isosceles triangle subtends an angle ϑ/n.
We may divide each isosceles triangle in half forming two right triangles (a total of 2n right triangles), each of their bases subtend an angle ϑ/2n.
The base of each right triangle is equal to R(sin(ϑ/2n))~R(ϑ/2n) (n→∞). Therefore, the sum of the 2n bases of the 2n right triangles is
∑=(2n)R(sin(ϑ/2n)) and when n→∞, ∑ → Rϑ=C.
Finally, π ≐ C/2R = ½ϑ.

NOTES:
